k m wrote:

>Generically stated, should a test method's setUp() and tearDown() rely on an untested method? If not, how can we avoid it? Is there a way to enforce the sequence of test method runs?
>  
>
The bottom line is this: the tests should break if something is wrong. 
If the test for deleting a record doesn't even get off the ground 
because there's a problem inside the add record method, then it still 
breaks, right? And vice-versa. Granted, with these dependencies, you've 
got potential for some situations that may be hard to figure out, or 
cases where one single problem causes many tests unnecessarily to break, 
but the red flags will still be thrown as soon as a bug creeps in, and 
that's the more important value.

The only real problems you have to look out for are cases where somehow 
the code is broken, but the tests still pass.

The other piece of advice to come to mind is to have different methods 
for adding and deleting that only the tests use -- don't re-use the 
production methods in your setUp()/tearDown(). I'd heard once the MS 
Excel team has two calculation engines to solve similar dilemmas. The 
production one is complex and optimized, the testing one is simpler and 
slow -- a lot of duplicated effort, but the only real way to verify the 
results of complex scenarios.

-- 
Chris
